_prev_prog_3.Description: Chooljian Brothers Packing Company has prepared a unified Risk & Process Safety Management Program. The program is in compliance with Californias Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program (in California CCR Title 19, Chapter 4.5 Program Level 3 Elements. At the Federal level, Title 40 CFR Part 68), and California OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) of Acutely Hazardous Materials standard (in California CCR Title 8, Section 5189, Process Safety Management of Acutely Hazardous Materials, and Federally Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119). This program has been prepared to address the risks involved with the presence of sulfur dioxide in an amount in excess of 5,000 lbs., which is used in our dehydration process.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. Executive Summary



This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program - Title 19 CCR, Chapter 4.5

- Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP) - Title 40 CFR ?68

- California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 8 CCR ?5189

-Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program, Title 29 CFR ?1910.119



Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP-PSM program.



This program is intended to be a "living document". As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Chooljian Brothers has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP-PSM related activities. 



1.1 Chooljian Brothers, Risk and Process Safety Management Program



This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Chooljian Brothers has developed their unified RMP-PSM Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which have the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 



Process Name                       | Process Chemical          | Process Quantity (lbs.)

Sulfur-Dioxide Dehydrating Process   Sulfur-Dioxide              8,000



Our RMP-PSM program promotes overall plant, worker, and public safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.



Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 

1. Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulation to meet

CalARP and RMP obligations as well

2. Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices

3. Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)



The RMP-PSM program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.



1.2 Process Description



Chooljian Brothers operates a dehydrating facility that utilizes sulfur dioxide chambers to preserve fruit color during the drying process. Sulfur dioxide is piped from a ton-container to each of the twenty-four (24) chambers using stainless-steel hose, aluminum pipe, and valves. When in use, each chamber receives 75-90 lb of sulfur dioxide gas and then remains sealed for 6-7 hrs afterwards.



The sulfur dioxide process consists of four ton containers which are not interconnected. The containers are co-located relative to each other and therefore all sulfur dioxide ton containers, pipe, and valves are treated as a single process.




RAGAGEP Statement



The process equipment was inspected during the 2018 PHA for the purpose of verifying that the process was designed, fabricated, and is being operated in accordance with applicable industry standards. It is unclear which codes and standards were followed in the design and construction gassing chambers. In the judgment of the PHA team, the process mostly closely aligns with CGA G-3 - 1995. This judgement was made because of the following:



Hose materials appear to comply with CGA G-3 - 1995 ?10.5 which requires hoses to be compatible 

with sulfur dioxide



Ton containers comply with CGA G-3 - 1995 ?7 with regard to DOT specifications



Lack of documentation specifying codes and standards used at the facility



1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps



1.3.1 General 



We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of sulfur dioxide

in annual safety meetings. During these meeting we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.



Chooljian Brothers has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the sulfur dioxide dehydrating process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 



1.3.2 Sulfur-Dioxide

The sulfur dioxide process at the Chooljian Brothers facility is an integral part of overall business and lasts for approximately five months out of the year. The sulfur dioxide process contains multiple cylinders with a maximum inventory of 8,000 (lbs.). It is extremely important that these areas and associated injection processes are maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Chooljian Brothers is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of exposure to sulfur dioxide.



Our personnel also monitor the sulfur dioxide dehydrating process and keep an active log of all associated procedures and transactions. In addition, the process is checked frequently during the season by the outside contractor that supplies the SO2 cylinders. The contractor also assists in performing the annual mechanical integrity review of our process equipment. 



1.4 Five Year Accident History



Chooljian Brothers has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.



1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan



Chooljian Brothers' emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:

- Cal/OSHA's Emergency Action Plan - Title 8 CCR ?3220

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans - Title 29 CFR ?1910.38

- Cal/OSHA's Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 8 CCR ?5189(n)

- U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administ

ration's (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements] - Title 29 CFR ?1910.119(n)

- California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4.5 ?2765.1-2765.2

- USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements] - Title 40 CFR ?68.95

- California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures] - Title 19 CCR, Division 2, Chapter 4 ?2731



Strategically, we will respond "minimally" to a release. Under this plan we will call emergency personnel and evacuate the facility. All response activities would be done in coordination with the Local Fire Department and their Hazardous Materials Response Team. 



Every year we review with our employees our evacuation procedures in the event of an emergency, including a hazardous chemical release.



1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Chooljian Brothers has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. Nevertheless, Chooljian Brothers continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.



By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP-PSM program. This has improved Chooljian Brothers' ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP-PSM related events so that Chooljian Brothers' management team can ensure that the RMP-PSM program is being implemented.



Chooljian Brothers has implemented all aspects of the RMP-PSM program. When a RMP-PSM program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A li

st of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.



In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Chooljian Brothers has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP-PSM program implementation.



For the future, Chooljian Brothers now thinks of the RMP-PSM program as a "living document". It is an interactive framework that guides safe action for Chooljian Brothers employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP-PSM program Chooljian Brothers will continue to maintain overall plant worker and public safety.
